text.div:
ComprehensiveMetabolic2000SerumOrPlasmaPanel Profile

Represents a comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel (CMP) from serum or plasma, which measures various components such as glucose, electrolytes, kidney function, and liver function. The components of this panel are not entirely standardized, so the definition of the CMP includes tests that are optional, or performed by certain laboratories but not others. Therefore, instances typically will include a subset of the listed panel members.

Mapping Summary

obf.lab.ComprehensiveMetabolic2000SerumOrPlasmaPanel maps to DiagnosticReport:
  Language maps to language
  ImplicitRules maps to implicitRules
  Metadata.VersionId maps to meta.versionId
  Metadata.SourceSystem maps to meta.extension
  Metadata.Profile maps to meta.profile
  Metadata.LastUpdated maps to meta.lastUpdated
  Metadata.SecurityLabel maps to meta.security
  Metadata.Tag maps to meta.tag
  Narrative maps to text
  Identifier maps to identifier
  Status maps to status
  Code maps to code
  Category maps to category
  ObservationSubjectOfRecord maps to subject
  CareContext maps to encounter
  RelevantTime maps to effective[x]
  StatementDateTime maps to issued
  DiagnosticReportPerformer maps to performer
  ResultsInterpreter maps to extension
  Specimen maps to specimen
  LaboratoryObservation maps to result (slice on = target.reference.resolve(); slice on type = profile; slice strategy = includes)
  MediaIncluded.CommentOrDescription maps to image.comment
  MediaIncluded.Media maps to image.link
  ConclusionText maps to conclusion
  ConclusionCode maps to codedDiagnosis
  PresentedForm maps to presentedForm

name: ComprehensiveMetabolic2000SerumOrPlasmaPanel
description: Represents a comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel (CMP) from serum or plasma, which measures various components such as glucose, electrolytes, kidney function, and liver function. The components of this panel are not entirely standardized, so the definition of the CMP includes tests that are optional, or performed by certain laboratories but not others. Therefore, instances typically will include a subset of the listed panel members.
requirements: To support reporting for any diagnostic report into a clinical data repository.

element.name: DiagnosticReport
element.short: obf-lab-ComprehensiveMetabolic2000SerumOrPlasmaPanel
element.definition: Represents a comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel (CMP) from serum or plasma, which measures various components such as glucose, electrolytes, kidney function, and liver function. The components of this panel are not entirely standardized, so the definition of the CMP includes tests that are optional, or performed by certain laboratories but not others. Therefore, instances typically will include a subset of the listed panel members.
element.comments: This is intended to capture a single report, and is not suitable for use in displaying summary information that covers multiple reports.  For example, this resource has not been designed for laboratory cumulative reporting formats nor detailed structured reports for sequencing.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.id
element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta
element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta.id
element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta.extension
element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: sourcesystem
element.definition:
FHIR: This provides a minimal amount of Provenance information that can be used to track or differentiate the source of information in the resource. The source may identify another FHIR server, document, message, database, etc.
FHIM: Identifies the computer system that created the medical record. This optional field may also be used to indicate that the medical record was originally created by a different organization from the one that is currently storing or utilizing the record in that the assigning authority of the Id could be set to that originating organization. This property is optional, as some systems will assume that all records that it contains originated in that system, however it is anticipated that it will become increasingly commonplace for records from multiple systems and organizations will be comingled in order to provide a complete picture of the patient's health record.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta.versionId
element.short: Version specific identifier
element.definition: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the URL. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comments: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta.lastUpdated
element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.definition: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comments: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta.profile
element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.definition: A list of profiles [[[StructureDefinition]]]s that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to [[[StructureDefinition.url]]].
element.comments: It is up to the server and/or other infrastructure of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over time.  The list of profile URLs is a set.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta.security
element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.definition: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comments: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource  The list of security labels is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

binding.description: Security Labels from the Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.meta.tag
element.short: Tags applied to this resource
element.definition: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comments: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.  The list of tags is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

binding.description: Codes that represent various types of tags, commonly workflow-related; e.g. "Needs review by Dr. Jones"

element.name: DiagnosticReport.implicitRules
element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.language
element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.name: DiagnosticReport.text
element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.contained
element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.extension
element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: resultsinterpreter
element.definition: The practitioner or organization that is responsible for the report's conclusions and interpretations.

element.name: basedon
element.definition: The proposal, order, or plan that is partly or wholly fulfilled by this item.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.modifierExtension
element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.identifier
element.short: Id for external references to this report
element.definition: The local ID assigned to the report by the order filler, usually by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider.
element.requirements: Need to know what identifier to use when making queries about this report from the source laboratory, and for linking to the report outside FHIR context.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.status
element.short: registered | partial | final | corrected | appended | cancelled | entered-in-error
element.definition: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications need to take appropriate action if a report is withdrawn.
element.requirements: Diagnostic services routinely issue provisional/incomplete reports, and sometimes withdraw previously released reports.

binding.description: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole.

mapping.map: statusCode  Note: final and amended are distinguished by whether observation is the subject of a ControlAct event of type "revise"

element.name: DiagnosticReport.category
element.short: Service category
element.definition: A code that classifies the clinical discipline, department or diagnostic service that created the report (e.g. cardiology, biochemistry, hematology, MRI). This is used for searching, sorting and display purposes.
element.comments: The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set. More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in DiagnosticReport.code.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code
element.short: Name/Code for this diagnostic report
element.definition: A code or name that describes this diagnostic report.

mapping.map: OBR-4 (HL7 v2 doesn't provide an easy way to indicate both the ordered test and the performed panel)

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.id
element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.extension
element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding
element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labelled as UserSelected = true.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.name: Fixed_24323-8
element.short: Comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel - Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel - Serum or Plasma

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding-Fixed-24323-8.id
element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding-Fixed-24323-8.extension
element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding-Fixed-24323-8.system
element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding-Fixed-24323-8.version
element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding-Fixed-24323-8.code
element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding-Fixed-24323-8.display
element.short: Representation defined by the system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.coding-Fixed-24323-8.userSelected
element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.name: DiagnosticReport.code.text
element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.name: DiagnosticReport.subject
element.short: The subject of an observation
element.definition: The subject of an observation.

mapping.map: PID-3 (no HL7 v2 mapping for Group or Device)

element.name: DiagnosticReport.encounter
element.short: Health care event when test ordered
element.definition: The link to the health care event (encounter) when the order was made.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.effectivex
element.short: Clinically Relevant time/time-period for report
element.definition: The time or time-period the observed values are related to. When the subject of the report is a patient, this is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection(s), but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
element.comments: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was performed. If there are specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.
element.requirements: Need to know where in the patient history to file/present this report.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.issued
element.short: DateTime this version was released
element.definition: The date and time that this version of the report was released from the source diagnostic service.
element.comments: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report.
element.requirements: Clinicians need to be able to check the date that the report was released.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.performer
element.short: Responsible Diagnostic Service
element.definition: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
element.comments: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items. It is the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.
element.requirements: Need to know whom to contact if there are queries about the results. Also may need to track the source of reports for secondary data analysis.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.request
element.short: What was requested
element.definition: Details concerning a test or procedure requested.
element.comments: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track completion of requests based on reports issued and also to report what diagnostic tests were requested (not always the same as what is delivered).

element.name: DiagnosticReport.specimen
element.short: Specimens this report is based on
element.definition: Details about the specimens on which this diagnostic report is based.
element.comments: If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the test result name, then this additional data may be redundant. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per Observation or group.
element.requirements: Need to be able to report information about the collected specimens on which the report is based.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.result
element.short: A coded finding based on a specimen, usually collected from a patient (but possibly from a location)
element.definition: A coded finding based on a specimen, usually collected from a patient (but possibly from a location).
element.requirements: Need to support individual results, or report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - observations can contain observations.

element.name: obf-lab-GlobulinMCncPtSerQnCalculatedLabObs
element.short: GlobulinMCncPtSerQnCalculatedLabObs: Globulin [Mass/​volume] in Serum by calculation
element.definition: Globulin [Mass/​volume] in Serum by calculation

element.name: obf-lab-AlanineAminotransferaseCCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: AlanineAminotransferaseCCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Alanine aminotransferase [Enzymatic activity/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Alanine aminotransferase [Enzymatic activity/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-AlbuminMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: AlbuminMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Albumin [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Albumin [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-AlbuminGlobulinMRtoPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: AlbuminGlobulinMRtoPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Albumin/​Globulin [Mass Ratio] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Albumin/​Globulin [Mass Ratio] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-CalciumMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: CalciumMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Calcium [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Calcium [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-AspartateAminotransferaseCCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: AspartateAminotransferaseCCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Aspartate aminotransferase [Enzymatic activity/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Aspartate aminotransferase [Enzymatic activity/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-BilirubinMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: BilirubinMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Bilirubin.total [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Bilirubin.total [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-CarbonDioxideSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: CarbonDioxideSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Carbon dioxide, total [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Carbon dioxide, total [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-ChlorideSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: ChlorideSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Chloride [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Chloride [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-CreatinineMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: CreatinineMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Creatinine [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Creatinine [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-GlucoseMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: GlucoseMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Glucose [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Glucose [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-PotassiumSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: PotassiumSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Potassium [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Potassium [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-ProteinMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: ProteinMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Protein [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Protein [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-SodiumSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: SodiumSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Sodium [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Sodium [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-UreaNitrogenMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: UreaNitrogenMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Urea nitrogen [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Urea nitrogen [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-UreaNitrogenCreatinineMRtoPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: UreaNitrogenCreatinineMRtoPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Urea nitrogen/​Creatinine [Mass Ratio] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Urea nitrogen/​Creatinine [Mass Ratio] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-AlkalinePhosphataseCCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: AlkalinePhosphataseCCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Alkaline phosphatase [Enzymatic activity/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Alkaline phosphatase [Enzymatic activity/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-GFR173sqMPredArVRatPtSerPlasQnMDRDLabObs
element.short: GFR173sqMPredArVRatPtSerPlasQnMDRDLabObs: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M.predicted [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum or Plasma by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD)
element.definition: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M.predicted [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum or Plasma by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD). Units are optional.

element.name: obf-lab-GFR173sqMPredFemaleArVRatPtSerPlasBldQnMDRDLabObs
element.short: GFR173sqMPredFemaleArVRatPtSerPlasBldQnMDRDLabObs: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M predicted among females [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum, Plasma or Blood by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD)
element.definition: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M predicted among females [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum, Plasma or Blood by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD). Units are optional.

element.name: obf-lab-GFR173sqMPredNonBlackArVRatPtSerPlasBldQnMDRDLabObs
element.short: GFR173sqMPredNonBlackArVRatPtSerPlasBldQnMDRDLabObs: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M predicted among non-blacks [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum, Plasma or Blood by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD)
element.definition: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M predicted among non-blacks [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum, Plasma or Blood by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD). Units are optional.

element.name: obf-lab-GFR173sqMPredBlackArVRatPtSerPlasBldQnMDRDLabObs
element.short: GFR173sqMPredBlackArVRatPtSerPlasBldQnMDRDLabObs: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M predicted among blacks [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum, Plasma or Blood by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD)
element.definition: Glomerular filtration rate/​1.73 sq M predicted among blacks [Volume Rate/​Area] in Serum, Plasma or Blood by Creatinine-based formula (MDRD). Units are optional.

element.name: obf-lab-BilirubinDirectMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: BilirubinDirectMCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Bilirubin.direct [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Bilirubin.direct [Mass/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-BicarbonateSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: BicarbonateSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Bicarbonate [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Bicarbonate [Moles/​volume] in Serum or Plasma

element.name: obf-lab-AniongapSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs
element.short: AniongapSCncPtSerPlasQnLabObs: Anion gap in Serum or Plasma. Units are optional but if provided, must be in mmol/L.
element.definition: Anion gap in Serum or Plasma. Units are optional but if provided, must be in mmol/L.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.imagingStudy
element.short: Reference to full details of imaging associated with the diagnostic report
element.definition: One or more links to full details of any imaging performed during the diagnostic investigation. Typically, this is imaging performed by DICOM enabled modalities, but this is not required. A fully enabled PACS viewer can use this information to provide views of the source images.
element.comments: ImagingStudy and ImageObjectStudy and the image element are somewhat overlapping - typically, the list of image references in the image element will also be found in one of the imaging study resources. However each caters to different types of displays for different types of purposes. Neither, either, or both may be provided.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.image
element.short: Key images associated with this report
element.definition: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).
element.requirements: Many diagnostic services include images in the report as part of their service.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.image.id
element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: DiagnosticReport.image.extension
element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.image.modifierExtension
element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.image.comment
element.short: Comment about the image (e.g. explanation)
element.definition: A comment about the image. Typically, this is used to provide an explanation for why the image is included, or to draw the viewer's attention to important features.
element.comments: The comment should be displayed with the image. It would be common for the report to include additional discussion of the image contents in other sections such as the conclusion.
element.requirements: The provider of the report should make a comment about each image included in the report.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.image.link
element.short: Reference to the image source
element.definition: Reference to the image source.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.conclusion
element.short: Clinical Interpretation of test results
element.definition: Concise and clinically contextualized narrative interpretation of the diagnostic report.
element.comments: Typically, a report is either [all data, no narrative (e.g. Core lab)] or [a mix of data with some concluding narrative (e.g. Structured Pathology Report, Bone Density)], or [all narrative (e.g. typical imaging report, histopathology)]. In all of these cases, the narrative goes in "text".
element.requirements: Need to be able to provide a conclusion that is not lost among the basic result data.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.codedDiagnosis
element.short: Codes for the conclusion
element.definition: Codes for the conclusion.

binding.description: Diagnoses codes provided as adjuncts to the report.

element.name: DiagnosticReport.presentedForm
element.short: Entire report as issued
element.definition: Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
element.comments: "application/pdf" is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.
element.requirements: Gives Laboratory the ability to provide its own fully formatted report for clinical fidelity.

element.name: DiagnosticReport
element.short: obf-lab-ComprehensiveMetabolic2000SerumOrPlasmaPanel
element.definition: Represents a comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel (CMP) from serum or plasma, which measures various components such as glucose, electrolytes, kidney function, and liver function. The components of this panel are not entirely standardized, so the definition of the CMP includes tests that are optional, or performed by certain laboratories but not others. Therefore, instances typically will include a subset of the listed panel members.

element.name: sourcesystem
element.definition:
FHIR: This provides a minimal amount of Provenance information that can be used to track or differentiate the source of information in the resource. The source may identify another FHIR server, document, message, database, etc.
FHIM: Identifies the computer system that created the medical record. This optional field may also be used to indicate that the medical record was originally created by a different organization from the one that is currently storing or utilizing the record in that the assigning authority of the Id could be set to that originating organization. This property is optional, as some systems will assume that all records that it contains originated in that system, however it is anticipated that it will become increasingly commonplace for records from multiple systems and organizations will be comingled in order to provide a complete picture of the patient's health record.

element.name: resultsinterpreter
element.definition: The practitioner or organization that is responsible for the report's conclusions and interpretations.

element.name: basedon
element.definition: The proposal, order, or plan that is partly or wholly fulfilled by this item.

element.name: Fixed_24323-8
element.short: Comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel - Serum or Plasma
element.definition: Comprehensive metabolic 2000 panel - Serum or Plasma

element.name: DiagnosticReport.result
element.short: A coded finding based on a specimen, usually collected from a patient (but possibly from a location)
element.definition: A coded finding based on a specimen, usually collected from a patient (but possibly from a location).
